task.title: Operating Instructions for the Supercharger
task.shortdesc: The supercharger is an integral part of your engine at all altitudes.

taskbody.context:
Don't fall into the trap of assuming that because you are operating at medium and low altitudes, your supercharger is not important. Your supercharger must have proper care all the time, regardless of whether you intend to use high blower.
Flight Instructions
Except where airfields are at extremely high altitudes, always take off in "LOW" blower. (There are no fields in the continental U.S. where "HIGH" blower take-offs are necessary.) While in "LOW" blower operate the engine as a single-speed supercharged engine.
Never operate in "HIGH" blower below 9,000 feet. The power gained by operating in "HIGH" blower below this altitude is offset by the power required to operate in "HIGH" blower. Make the shift from "LOW" to "HIGH" blower between 11,000 and 13,000 feet depending on the need for additional power.

stepsection.p: Shift From Low Blower To High Blower:

step.cmd: Reduce manifold pressure. (Reduce throttles sufficiently to prevent the surge in manifold pressure exceeding the prescribed power setting when the shift is made.)
Shift the controls rapidly and evenly from "LOW" to "HIGH," and lock. Make this a quick, positive action.

info.note: Never operate in "HIGH" blower below 1500 rpm. During prolonged operation in "HIGH" blower, change to "LOW" blower for 15 minutes every 2 hours, (This removes sludge from the clutch.)

stepsection.p: Shift From High Blower To Low Blower.

step.cmd: Reduce throttles. (Your manifold pressure must not exceed the setting for 1700 rpm.)
Shift the controls from "HIGH" to "LOW" in a quick, positive action.

info.note: For maximum performance above 12,000 ft. reduce rpm to 2400. This adds 5 to 8 mph. to the maximum speed.
